bugDrugPairs.hint: Most common cause of neonatal sepsis <7 days
Second most common neonatal meningitis. K1 capsule crosses BBB
Cephalosporins are NOT effective. Use Ampicillin or TMP-SMX
High-dose cephalosporin; add Vancomycin for meningitis empirically
Rapid progression. Check for petechial rash. Start antibiotics before LP if suspected

bugDrugPairs.context: Meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia (now rare with Hib vaccine)
bugDrugPairs.hint: Vaccine-preventable. Still see in unvaccinated populations
MSSA (methicillin-sensitive). Beta-lactam preferred over Vancomycin
MRSA (methicillin-resistant). Clindamycin if susceptible; Vancomycin if serious
First-line for GAS. No resistance; erythromycin/azithromycin alternative
Macrolide is first-line. Vaccine-preventable (DTaP). Limited role for antibiotics if late catarrhal stage
Staccato cough in pneumonia. Prophylaxis with erythromycin ointment at birth prevents inclusion conjunctivitis

bugDrugPairs.context: Gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum, gonorrhea in adolescents
bugDrugPairs.hint: Ceftriaxone monotherapy now recommended. Add azithromycin for presumed co-infection with Chlamydia in older children
Atypical organism. Walking pneumonia. X-ray shows bilateral lower lobe infiltrates
Viral—no routine antiviral. Watch for secondary bacterial infection

bugDrugPairs.context: Neonatal herpes, CNS disease, disseminated infection
bugDrugPairs.hint: High mortality if untreated. Vesicular skin lesions, seizures, CSF with RBCs and monocytes. Start empirically if suspected
Oral Acyclovir for uncomplicated varicella in immunocompetent. IV for severe/disseminated
Sickle cell disease patients at high risk for Salmonella osteomyelitis (bone tropism)
Salmonella OSTEOMYELITIS is pathognomonic for sickle cell. Treat aggressively

bugDrugPairs.context: Cystic fibrosis, burn wounds, P. aeruginosa pneumonia
bugDrugPairs.hint: Requires double coverage. Aminoglycoside + antipseudomonal penicillin or cephalosporin

bugDrugPairs.context: Osteomyelitis/septic arthritis in young children (1-4 years)
bugDrugPairs.hint: Fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus. Most common cause of septic arthritis in toddlers (replacing S. aureus)
History of cat scratch or exposure. Regional lymphadenopathy. Usually self-limited
Tick exposure in endemic area. Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash) is pathognomonic. Doxycycline preferred in older kids
CD4 <200 in HIV. Bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Prophylaxis also with TMP-SMX

bugDrugPairs.drug: Fluconazole or IV Amphotericin B (if invasive)
bugDrugPairs.context: Oral thrush, esophageal candidiasis, bloodstream infection
bugDrugPairs.hint: Common in premature infants and immunocompromised. Fluconazole for most; Amphotericin for invasive/CNS
Pseudomembranous colitis. Risk after broad-spectrum antibiotics (clindamycin, cephalosporins)
Most common helminth in developed countries. Treat whole family. Reinfection common

bugDrugPairs.context: Congenital syphilis, early or late manifestations
bugDrugPairs.hint: VDRL/RPR screening mandatory in prenatal care. Penicillin prevents vertical transmission

bugDrugPairs.drug: Benzathine Penicillin G (IM single dose) or Doxycycline
bugDrugPairs.hint: Primary: chancre. Secondary: rash (including palms/soles), lymphadenopathy, fever
Alpha-hemolytic streptococci. Slow growth; need blood cultures. Often follows dental procedure
Late-onset GBS (≥7 days) has different empiric coverage than early-onset
Beta-lactamase production confers ampicillin resistance. High-dose amoxicillin-clavulanate is first-line AOM
Saltwater exposure. Can cause severe septicemia, especially in immunocompromised

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Add IV Acyclovir empirically if any concern for HSV (vesicles, maternal genital lesions). Avoid ceftriaxone in neonates due to bilirubin displacement and kernicterus risk. CSF findings: low glucose, high protein, neutrophil predominance in bacterial; lymphocytes early in viral.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture and sensitivity at 48-72 hours. If Listeria identified, continue Ampicillin; cephalosporins do not penetrate CNS adequately for Listeria
empiricTherapy.duration: 14-21 days for GBS; 21 days for gram-negative rods; 14-21 days for HSV

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Risk factors: maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes, prematurity, low birth weight. Blood cultures before antibiotics. Maternal GBS status guides decision; if mother unknown/positive, treat. Do NOT do LP in unstable neonates—treat presumptively.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Blood culture results (24-48h). If cultures negative and baby well, may discontinue after 48h
empiricTherapy.duration: 7-10 days if confirmed bacterial; 10-14 days if meningitis

empiricTherapy.syndrome: Neonatal Late-Onset Sepsis (LOS, ≥72 hours to 28 days)
empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Vancomycin + Gentamicin (± Cefotaxime for meningitis coverage)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Nosocomial pathogens predominate. Central line associated. Vancomycin dosing: 10-15 mg/kg/dose Q8-12h (goal trough 10-20 mcg/mL). Consider Candida empirically, especially in preemies and prolonged antibiotics. Add fluconazole if risk high.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture results and susceptibilities. Remove central line if infected
empiricTherapy.duration: 7-14 days depending on pathogen and source control

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin (+ Ampicillin if <3 months or risk factors for Listeria)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Start antibiotics BEFORE LP if meningitis suspected clinically (petechiae, altered mental status, kernig/brudzinski sign). Dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg Q6h for 4 days (improves outcomes, especially pneumococcal). High-dose cephalosporin; add Vancomycin for empiric coverage of resistant pneumococcus. Listeria coverage only if age <3 months or immunocompromised.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: CSF culture and sensitivity (24-48h). If S. pneumoniae susceptible to penicillin, can narrow to penicillin alone. If H. influenzae, switch to ceftriaxone/cefotaxime if not already using.

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Amoxicillin (first-line) or Ceftriaxone (if unable to tolerate PO or severe)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: High-dose amoxicillin (80-90 mg/kg/day) for resistant pneumococcus. Viral causes (RSV, influenza) are common; antibiotics for bacterial superinfection. Assess severity: mild-moderate usually PO; severe/hypoxia/tachypnea needs IV therapy.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Clinical response. Cultures not routinely done unless severe/hospitalized

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Mycoplasma increasingly common in school-age and adolescents (walking pneumonia, minimal infiltrates). If Mycoplasma suspected, use azithromycin or doxycycline (if >8y). Atypical coverage may be needed empirically in some settings.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Clinical response and local resistance patterns. Consider Mycoplasma serology or PCR if atypical presentation

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: High-dose amoxicillin compensates for resistant pneumococcus. Amoxicillin-clavulanate if beta-lactamase producing H. influenzae suspected. Cephalosporin (cefotaxime, ceftriaxone) second-line if amoxicillin allergy or resistance.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Not typically done; treat empirically and assess clinical response

empiricTherapy.syndrome: Febrile Infant with UTI (2-24 months, fever, no obvious source)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: All febrile infants <2 years need urinalysis/culture as part of sepsis workup. Imaging (ultrasound ± VCUG) after acute infection to rule out anatomic abnormality. Positive UA (nitrites, WBCs) in febrile infant warrants IV antibiotics even if source unknown.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Urine culture results (24-48h). Switch to appropriate agent based on organism and susceptibilities
empiricTherapy.duration: 7-14 days (parenteral initially, may step-down to PO after clinical improvement)

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Purulent cellulitis with abscess/drainage changes management (now likely MRSA). Non-purulent (streptococcus) traditionally covered by beta-lactam. Clinical response is key. If worsening, add MRSA coverage.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Clinical improvement. Culture if purulent or severe

empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Purulent drainage mandates MRSA coverage. Perform incision and drainage; send culture. Clindamycin effective if susceptible; reduces toxin production. Some centers use linezolid or daptomycin for resistant MRSA.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture results and susceptibilities. If MSSA, narrow to nafcillin or cephalosporin

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: IV Beta-lactam ± Vancomycin (Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone ± Vancomycin)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Urgent CT/MRI to rule out orbital cellulitis/abscess. All cases get IV antibiotics. Orbital cellulitis (exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, vision loss) needs surgical drainage. Periorbital cellulitis may be treated with IV abx alone.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture results and imaging findings. If abscess present, surgical drainage needed
empiricTherapy.duration: 10-14 days IV, then transition to PO completion

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: IV Beta-lactam or Vancomycin (Cefotaxime or Nafcillin ± Vancomycin for empiric S. aureus coverage)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Joint aspiration mandatory for culture and gram stain. Blood cultures. Imaging (X-ray, ultrasound, MRI) localizes infection. Kingella kingae now most common cause of septic arthritis in toddlers. Early surgery if complicated (foreign body, subperiosteal abscess).
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture results. If susceptibilities available, narrow to MSSA coverage (nafcillin preferred over cephalosporin) if organism is MSSA
empiricTherapy.duration: 3-4 weeks IV for osteomyelitis; 2-3 weeks for septic arthritis (may switch to PO if good response)

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime (± Vancomycin if unsure of resistance)
targetOrganisms: Haemophilus influenzae type b (rare now with vaccine)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: AIRWAY EMERGENCY. Visualize epiglottis in controlled setting (OR, not bedside). Drooling, tripoding, toxic appearance. Do not agitate child. Lateral neck X-ray may show 'thumb sign.' Antibiotics STAT; consider dexamethasone. Airway may need intubation.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture results rare (airway swabs). Treat empirically with high-dose cephalosporin

empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Amoxicillin or Penicillin (first-line) or Cephalosporin (if allergy)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Confirmed by rapid strep or throat culture (not empiric antibiotics without testing—avoid unnecessary therapy). Amoxicillin preferred over Penicillin (better taste, dosing). No resistance to penicillin. Erythromycin/azithromycin if penicillin allergy (non-IgE mediated).
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Culture confirms GAS. All penicillin-susceptible; no narrowing needed
empiricTherapy.duration: 10 days (full course required to prevent acute rheumatic fever)

empiricTherapy.syndrome: Neonatal Conjunctivitis (Inclusion body conjunctivitis from Chlamydia)
empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Azithromycin (or Erythromycin eye ointment for prophylaxis)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Prophylaxis: erythromycin ointment at birth prevents chlamydial and gonococcal. Chlamydia presents at 1-2 weeks with mild conjunctivitis (non-purulent). Gonorrhea presents acutely with profuse purulent discharge. Always screen mother and treat maternal infection.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Conjunctival culture and gram stain identify organism. Treat mother and sexual partners

empiricTherapy.syndrome: Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) - Adolescent with gonorrhea
empiricTherapy.empiricRegimen: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose (or Doxycycline 100 mg BID x7 if >8y)
empiricTherapy.keyConsiderations: Dual therapy now standard (Chlamydia coverage mandatory). Fluoroquinolones no longer recommended due to resistance. Screen for other STIs (syphilis, HIV, HSV). Partners need treatment. Report to public health.
empiricTherapy.whenToNarrow: Chlamydia testing; if negative, azithromycin theoretically unnecessary but given due to prevalence
empiricTherapy.duration: Single dose ceftriaxone + single dose azithromycin

antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: First-line for many common pediatric infections. High-dose compensates for resistant pneumococcus. Rash common with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) co-infection (not true allergy).
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: IgE-mediated penicillin allergy (Type I hypersensitivity—urticaria, anaphylaxis). Safely used in non-IgE mediated reactions (delayed rash).

antibioticSpectrum.mechanism: Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase, protecting amoxicillin from destruction
anaerobes: Anaerobic gram-positives and gram-negatives (better than amoxicillin alone)
pedsUses: Acute otitis media (if beta-lactamase-producing organism suspected)
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: Preferred over plain amoxicillin for AOM if there's concern for beta-lactamase-producing H. influenzae. Higher diarrhea rate than amoxicillin alone due to clavulanate.
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Penicillin allergy (Type I), cephalosporin allergy, cholestasis history

antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: ESSENTIAL for neonatal coverage because Listeria monocytogenes is a neonatal pathogen. Cephalosporins do NOT cover Listeria—this is a high-yield shelf exam point. Used IV in neonates/severe infections.

gramNegative: Excellent gram-negative coverage: H. influenzae, Neisseria, Enterobacteriaceae, some Pseudomonas
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: AVOID in neonates—displaces bilirubin from albumin, causing kernicterus. Use cefotaxime instead in neonates. Excellent tissue penetration including CNS. Third-generation coverage for resistant organisms.

pedsUses: Neonatal meningitis (preferred over ceftriaxone in neonates)
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: PREFERRED in neonates over ceftriaxone (does not displace bilirubin as much). Excellent CNS penetration. Metabolism: hepatic de-esterification.
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Cephalosporin allergy, immediate hypersensitivity to penicillin (cross-reactivity <3%)

pedsUses: Step-down therapy for skin/soft tissue infections (MSSA)
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: Oral form only. First-gen coverage limited but adequate for MSSA. Good for step-down from IV beta-lactams once organism identified.
Excellent atypical coverage. Single-dose azithromycin for post-exposure pertussis prophylaxis. Good option for allergic-to-penicillin patients with GAS.

Good choice for empiric MRSA coverage, especially if susceptibilities show susceptibility. Excellent anaerobic coverage—useful for aspiration or intra-abdominal infections. AVOID overuse due to C. difficile risk.
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Lincosamide allergy, C. difficile colitis history

gramNegative: Excellent: E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella, H. influenzae
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: AVOIDED in neonates <2 months due to kernicterus risk (displaces bilirubin). Contraindicated in G6PD deficiency. Monitor CBC for bone marrow suppression.
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: G6PD deficiency, sulfonamide allergy, neonates <2 months, megaloblastic anemia, folate deficiency

gramPositive: Excellent: Streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA)
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: Requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM). Target troughs: 10-20 mcg/mL (most), 15-20 mcg/mL (meningitis). Nephrotoxicity risk, especially with aminoglycosides. Red man syndrome if infused too fast.
sideEffects: Red man syndrome (flushing, pruritus with rapid infusion)
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Vancomycin allergy (rare), caution in renal disease and hearing impairment

pedsUses: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (FIRST-LINE at ANY age despite age <8 restriction)
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: CRITICAL SHELF EXAM POINT: Doxycycline is CONTRAINDICATED in children <8 years due to permanent tooth discoloration and enamel hypoplasia. EXCEPTION: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) is life-threatening and doxycycline is first-line at ANY age. This exception is HIGH-YIELD for NBME.
sideEffects: Permanent tooth discoloration and enamel hypoplasia (if <8 years)
Esophageal ulceration if not taken with water
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Age <8 years (with RMSF exception), pregnancy, esophageal obstruction

antibioticSpectrum.mechanism: Protein synthesis inhibition and cell wall disruption (30S ribosome)
gramPositive: Synergy with beta-lactams (gram-positive) for serious infections
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: Used synergistically with ampicillin/amoxicillin in neonates and febrile infants. Extended-interval dosing preferred (once daily) for convenience and possibly better outcomes. Requires TDM. Peak/trough monitoring essential.
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Aminoglycoside allergy, renal disease (caution), hearing impairment

anaerobes: Excellent: Bacteroides, Clostridium, Prevotella, Peptostreptococcus, Fusobacterium
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: NO activity against aerobes—must be combined with beta-lactam or other agents for mixed infections. Poorly tolerated in children (taste, GI upset). IV form available for serious infections.

antibioticSpectrum.mechanism: Inhibits viral DNA polymerase (requires viral thymidine kinase)
pedsUses: Neonatal herpes simplex (IV)—CRITICAL for early recognition
antibioticSpectrum.pedsNotes: IV formulation critical for neonatal HSV. High doses required (10-15 mg/kg/dose Q8h for meningitis). CNS penetration adequate. Nephrotoxicity if dehydrated—ensure good urine output.
sideEffects: Tremors, confusion, hallucinations (encephalopathy, especially if renal failure)
antibioticSpectrum.contraindications: Acyclovir allergy, severe renal disease (adjust dosing)

clues: Vesicular lesions on scalp and face
whatsTheBug.explanation: Neonatal HSV presents with skin vesicles, CNS disease (encephalitis with temporal lobe predilection), and disseminated disease. Risk is vertical transmission from maternal genital herpes, especially during delivery. CSF shows elevated WBCs with both lymphocytes and monocytes, and RBCs (hemorrhagic pattern). Mortality without treatment is >50%.

clues: Maternal fever, rupture of membranes >18 hours
whatsTheBug.explanation: GBS is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis in the first 72 hours (early-onset). Vertical transmission from maternal colonization during delivery. Risk factors: maternal fever, prolonged ROM, prematurity, low birthweight. Presents with sepsis: respiratory distress, temperature instability, poor perfusion.

N. meningitidis is a rapidly progressive bacterial meningitis with characteristic petechial/purpuric rash. Presents with meningeal signs, sepsis, and potential meningococcemia (sepsis with rash). Rash may evolve to purpura fulminans (DIC). Requires immediate antibiotics before LP if suspected clinically.

clues: History of maternal exposure to sexually transmitted disease
whatsTheBug.explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis causes inclusion conjunctivitis at 1-2 weeks (mild, non-purulent) and can progress to pneumonia at 3-8 weeks with characteristic staccato cough and hyperinflation/interstitial infiltrates on CXR. Prophylaxis with erythromycin ointment at birth prevents infection.

clues: Cough starts after runny nose (catarrhal phase)
Fever and coryza in first 2 weeks
whatsTheBug.explanation: Pertussis progresses through catarrhal phase (mild URI symptoms), paroxysmal phase (severe paroxysmal cough with post-tussive vomiting, inspiratory whoop), and convalescent phase. Post-exposure prophylaxis with azithromycin is important for contacts. Vaccine-preventable (DTaP).

clues: 3-year-old with maculopapular rash starting on face
Koplik spots on buccal mucosa (white spots)
whatsTheBug.explanation: Measles presents with prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (3 Cs). Koplik spots (small white spots with red halos on buccal mucosa) appear 2-3 days before rash and are pathognomonic. Rash starts at hairline/face and spreads cephalocaudally (head to toe). Vaccine-preventable (MMR).

clues: 5-year-old with pink maculopapular rash on face/trunk
whatsTheBug.explanation: Rubella presents with mild systemic symptoms, pink-red maculopapular rash starting on face and spreading downward, and arthralgias/arthritis (more common in older children and adults). Koplik spots are absent (unlike measles). Congenital rubella causes cataracts, heart defects, and deafness.

clues: Rose-pink maculopapular rash AFTER fever resolves
whatsTheBug.explanation: Roseola is classically high fever followed by rash defervescence (fever breaks, then rash appears). Rose-pink maculopapular rash on trunk and neck. Most common in children 6 months to 3 years. Febrile seizures common during high fever phase. Self-limited.

clues: 4-year-old with vesicular rash in handprint distribution
whatsTheBug.explanation: Hand-foot-mouth disease presents with oral ulcers on soft palate/anterior oral pillars, and vesicular rash on hands, feet, and buttocks in a painful/clustered pattern. Usually mild systemic symptoms. Most common cause is Coxsackievirus A16.

clues: 6-year-old with lacy reticular rash on cheeks
History of fifth disease exposure in classroom
whatsTheBug.explanation: Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum with characteristic slapped-cheek appearance (bright red confluent erythema on cheeks) and lacy reticular rash on trunk/extremities. Mild systemic symptoms. Arthralgia more common in adults. Self-limited.

clues: 8-year-old with diffuse vesicular rash in crops
Lesions in different stages of healing
whatsTheBug.explanation: Varicella presents with crops of vesicular lesions in different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, crusts all present simultaneously). Preceded by fever and malaise. Highly contagious. Vaccine-preventable (Varicella). Complications: secondary bacterial infection, encephalitis, pneumonia.

clues: 4-year-old with sandpaper-like rash on trunk/flexor surfaces
whatsTheBug.answer: Scarlet fever (Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis with toxin)
whatsTheBug.explanation: Scarlet fever is Group A Streptococcal pharyngitis complicated by rash from erythrogenic toxin. Presents with pharyngitis, fever, and fine sandpaper-like rash starting on trunk and spreading. Strawberry tongue (red papillae on white coating early, then coated red tongue). Pastia lines (darker in skin folds).

Non-bullous impetigo presents with golden/honey-crusted lesions, often on lower extremities. Usually caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus. Follows minor skin trauma or insect bites. Highly contagious. Bullous impetigo is caused by S. aureus (exfoliative toxins).

clues: Peeling on hands/feet in recovery phase
whatsTheBug.explanation: Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis presenting with fever >5 days, polymorphous rash (not vesicular), conjunctival injection (non-exudative), oral changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips), cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity edema. Peak incidence 1-5 years, but also older children. Can cause coronary artery aneurysms—requires urgent treatment with IVIG and aspirin.

clues: History of cat scratch 2-3 weeks ago
whatsTheBug.explanation: Cat scratch disease presents with regional lymphadenopathy (usually 2-3 weeks after inoculation) without systemic toxicity. Most common in children. Caused by Bartonella henselae. Diagnosis by PCR, culture on special media, or serology. Usually self-limited but can be treated with azithromycin.

clues: Recent tick exposure in endemic area
whatsTheBug.explanation: Lyme disease presents with erythema migrans (expanding erythematous rash, often with central clearing—bull's-eye appearance) after tick bite in endemic area. Early disseminated: multiple EM lesions, arthralgia/arthritis, cranial nerve palsies. Treated with doxycycline (if >8 years) or amoxicillin (if <8 years).

clues: 3-year-old with acute limp (refusing to bear weight)
Limited range of motion of hip
whatsTheBug.answer: Septic arthritis (hip joint), likely Staphylococcus aureus or Kingella kingae
whatsTheBug.explanation: Septic arthritis presents with acute monoarticular joint pain, fever, and refusal to bear weight. Hip is most common in young children. Kingella kingae is now most common cause in toddlers (1-4 years). Requires joint aspiration for gram stain, culture, and cell count. Treatment: IV antibiotics ± surgical drainage.

Acute osteomyelitis presents with fever, acute bone pain (usually femur or tibia metaphysis), edema/erythema, and elevated inflammatory markers. Usually preceded by bacteremia. Most common cause: Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA). Requires blood cultures, imaging (X-ray, MRI), and IV antibiotics ± surgical drainage.

clues: 4-year-old with acute onset stridor and respiratory distress
whatsTheBug.explanation: Epiglottitis is a medical emergency presenting with stridor, drooling, dysphagia, respiratory distress, and toxic appearance. AIRWAY is at risk. Classically caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b (now rare due to vaccination). Diagnosis: lateral neck X-ray (thumb sign). Treatment: airway management, antibiotics, dexamethasone. Do NOT agitate patient.

Croup presents with barky seal-like cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Usually viral (parainfluenza most common). Follows URI prodrome. Most common in 6 months to 3 years. Mild cases treat with dexamethasone; severe cases may need epinephrine. Rarely requires intubation.

Bronchiolitis presents with wheezing, crackles, respiratory distress, and hyperinflation in infants <2 years. Most common cause: RSV, but also parainfluenza, influenza, parainfluenza. Viral disease—antibiotics not indicated unless bacterial superinfection. Supportive care (oxygen, hydration). Ribavirin reserved for severe/immunocompromised.

Gonococcal ophthalmia presents with profuse purulent conjunctivitis at 2-5 days of life (acute onset). Much more severe than chlamydial conjunctivitis. Risk of corneal scarring if untreated. Prophylaxis with silver nitrate or antibiotics at birth prevents infection. Treatment: single-dose IV or IM ceftriaxone.

clues: 10-year-old girl with severe itching in perianal region at night
Worm-like threads visible on perianal area
whatsTheBug.explanation: Pinworm infection presents with severe perianal itching especially at night (female worms migrate out to lay eggs). Patients may complain of visible worms. Most common helminth in developed countries. Diagnosis: Scotch tape test. Treatment: mebendazole or pyrantel pamoate (treat family members).

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Erythematous macules starting at hairline and face, spreading cephalocaudally (head to toe). Non-blanching. Preceded by cough, coryza, conjunctivitis (3 Cs). Koplik spots (white spots with red halos on buccal mucosa) appear BEFORE rash.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Koplik spots appear 2-3 days BEFORE rash—pathognomonic. Cephalocaudal spread.

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Pink-red maculopapular rash starting on face, spreading downward. Usually on trunk and extremities. Milder than measles. No Koplik spots.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Absence of Koplik spots (unlike measles). Milder prodrome. Arthralgia/arthritis especially in adolescent girls.
complications: Congenital rubella (if maternal infection in first trimester): cataracts, cardiac defects, deafness, microcephaly

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Rose-pink maculopapular rash appearing AFTER high fever (3-5 days) resolves. Non-pruritic. Trunk and neck predominance. Blanching.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Fever THEN rash (fever defervescence followed by rash appearance). Febrile seizures common during high fever phase.

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Lacy reticular rash ('lace-like' pattern) on trunk and extremities. Bright red slapped-cheek appearance on face with circumoral pallor. Blanching.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Slapped-cheek appearance (bright red confluent erythema on cheeks). Lacy reticular rash on trunk.
complications: Arthralgia/arthritis (more common in adults, especially women)
Hydrops fetalis (if maternal infection in first trimester)

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Vesicular lesions in grouped clusters on hands, feet, and perioral region. Oral ulcers on soft palate and anterior pillars. Painful vesicles.
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Enterovirus (Coxsackievirus A16 most common, also A5, A7, A9, A10; Enterovirus 71)
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Vesicles on hands, feet, and perioral region (not generalized). Oral ulcers on soft palate (NOT on hard palate as in herpes).

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Crops of vesicles in different stages of development (macules, papules, vesicles, pustules, crusts all present simultaneously). Centripetal distribution (trunk >> face/extremities). Very pruritic.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: 'Dew drops on rose petals'—lesions in different stages simultaneously. Centripetal distribution.
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: Supportive care. Acyclovir if severe or immunocompromised (or >12 hours after onset if immunocompromised).

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Fine sandpaper-like rash starting on trunk and flexor surfaces (antecubital/inguinal areas, etc.). Pastia lines (darker in skin folds). Associated with strawberry tongue and pharyngitis.
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) with erythrogenic toxin production
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Sandpaper-like texture. Strawberry tongue (red papillae early, then coated red tongue). Pastia lines in skin folds.
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: Penicillin or Amoxicillin (10-day course to prevent acute rheumatic fever)
complications: Acute rheumatic fever (if untreated for GAS)

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Golden/honey-crusted lesions, non-bullous appearance. Usually on lower extremities (legs, shins). Preceded by minor skin trauma or insect bite.
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Streptococcus pyogenes (most common) or Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA)
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Golden/honey-crusted lesions (pathognomonic). Non-bullous type is more common (70-80%).
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: Topical antibiotics (mupirocin) for localized; systemic antibiotics if widespread or bullous form

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Petechial rash (small non-blanching red/purple spots) spreading rapidly from trunk to extremities. May progress to purpura fulminans (large purpuric lesions, necrotic centers). Associated with sepsis symptoms.
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Non-blanching petechial/purpuric rash. Rapid progression. Associated with meningeal signs and sepsis.
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: IV Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone STAT, plus Vancomycin if resistant meningococcus possible. Consider Dexamethasone.

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Polymorphous rash (multiple morphologies—macular, urticarial, vesicular) not conforming to any single pattern. Associated with fever >5 days, conjunctival injection (non-exudative), oral changes, extremity edema.
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Unknown etiology (possibly infectious trigger + genetic predisposition)
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Polymorphous rash + fever >5 days + conjunctival injection (non-exudative) + oral changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips) + extremity edema. Peak age 1-5 years.
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: IVIG + high-dose aspirin (urgent to prevent coronary artery aneurysms)

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Erythema migrans: expanding erythematous macule or patch, often with central clearing (bull's-eye appearance). Usually >5 cm, solitary or multiple. Associated with tick exposure in endemic area.
rashToDiagnosis.diagnosis: Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi), early localized or disseminated
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Borrelia burgdorferi (spirochete), transmitted by Ixodes dammini tick
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Erythema migrans (bull's-eye appearance) at site of tick bite. Tick exposure in endemic area (Northeast, Midwest US).
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: Doxycycline (if >8 years) or Amoxicillin (if <8 years) for early Lyme; later stages may require IV Ceftriaxone
complications: Early disseminated: multiple EM lesions, arthritis, carditis (AV block), cranial nerve palsies
Late: Lyme arthritis, acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans

rashToDiagnosis.rashDescription: Petechial and pustular rash, small vesicles on face/trunk. Associated with fever, headache, and joint pain. Eschar (black necrotic center) may be present at tick bite site.
rashToDiagnosis.pathogen: Rickettsia rickettsii (obligate intracellular bacterium), transmitted by Dermacentor tick
rashToDiagnosis.keyFeature: Petechial rash starting on wrists/ankles, spreading centripetally (trunk). Eschar at bite site. Tick exposure.
rashToDiagnosis.treatment: Doxycycline (FIRST-LINE even if <8 years—RMSF is life-threatening exception to doxycycline age restriction). Start empirically if suspected.

contraindications: Encephalopathy within 7 days of prior dose
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Acellular pertussis now standard. Pregnant women get Tdap (27-36 weeks) each pregnancy for neonatal protection.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: Pertussis immunity wanes. Adolescent Tdap booster critical. Pregnant women receive Tdap each pregnancy.

contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Replaced OPV in US. No VDPV risk. Polio endemic in only Afghanistan and Pakistan as of 2024.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: IPV standard in US. Polio near eradication globally.

vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Live vaccine—space 28 days from other live vaccines. Measles extremely contagious (R0 ~15).
vaccineSchedule.highYield: Live vaccine—critical contraindication in immunocompromised. Pregnancy is absolute contraindication.

vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Live vaccine. Can give same day as MMR. Post-exposure prophylaxis within 3-5 days of varicella exposure.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: Live vaccine. Immunocompromised children get VariZIG (varicella-zoster immunoglobulin) for post-exposure instead.

vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: All neonates vaccinated at birth. Maternal HBsAg+ requires HBIg + vaccine at birth. Prevents chronic HBV (90% if infected as infant).
vaccineSchedule.highYield: Universal neonatal HBV. Maternal HBsAg+ = HBIg + vaccine. Prevents chronic infection and liver cancer.

contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Recommended for all children, travelers, PWID, MSM, chronic liver disease.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: HAV vaccine routine for all children >12 months. Safe and effective.

vaccineSchedule.fullName: Haemophilus influenzae type b Conjugate Vaccine
contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Hib meningitis, epiglottitis now rare in vaccinated populations. Non-typeable H. influenzae not covered.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: One of most successful vaccines. Epiglottitis now rare due to Hib vaccination.

contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: PCV13 covers 13 serotypes. Serotype 19A resistance—high-dose amoxicillin compensates.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: PCV13 reduced invasive disease. Serotype replacement important. Watch emerging resistant serotypes.

vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Oral live vaccine. Must complete before age window (8 months RotaTeq, 6 months Rotarix) due to intussusception risk.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: Rotavirus vaccine prevents severe gastroenteritis. Live vaccine with specific age window.

vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Prevents HPV-related cancers (cervical, anal, oropharyngeal). Boys AND girls vaccinated. Give up to age 26 if not previously vaccinated.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: HPV vaccine prevents cancer. Age 11-12 recommended. Girls and boys both need vaccination.

vaccineSchedule.booster: Booster at 16-18 years or 1 year after first
contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Covers serogroups A, C, W, Y. Does NOT cover B (needs separate MenB). College students highly recommended.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: MenACWY at 11-12y, booster 16-18y. MenB is SEPARATE. Both recommended for adolescents.

contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to any component
vaccineSchedule.pedsNotes: Separate from MenACWY. Covers serogroup B (common in developed countries). Meningococcal disease has rapid progression.
vaccineSchedule.highYield: MenB SEPARATE from MenACWY. Give both. Serogroup B has high mortality if untreated.

clinicalPearls.pearl: In neonatal meningitis, AVOID ceftriaxone—use cefotaxime instead. Ceftriaxone displaces bilirubin from albumin and can cause kernicterus.
Cephalosporins DO NOT cover Listeria monocytogenes. Neonatal meningitis requires Ampicillin to cover Listeria.
Doxycycline causes permanent tooth discoloration in children <8 years—EXCEPT for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF), which is a life-threatening exception. Use doxycycline at ANY age for RMSF.
Kingella kingae is now the MOST common cause of septic arthritis in toddlers (1-4 years), replacing Staphylococcus aureus.
Salmonella osteomyelitis is PATHOGNOMONIC for sickle cell disease. Other patients get S. aureus osteomyelitis.

GBS (Group B Streptococcus) causes early-onset sepsis (<72 hours), while Listeria and gram-negatives cause both early- and late-onset sepsis. Late-onset GBS (≥7 days) requires different empiric coverage.
Neonatal conjunctivitis prophylaxis with erythromycin ointment prevents chlamydial inclusion conjunctivitis AND gonococcal ophthalmia.
Koplik spots (white spots with red halos on buccal mucosa) appear BEFORE measles rash and are pathognomonic. They precede the rash by 2-3 days.
Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia presents with STACCATO cough (repetitive bursts of short coughs) at 3-8 weeks of life. Bilateral diffuse infiltrates on CXR.
Roseola infantum (HHV-6) presents with FEVER THEN RASH (unlike other exanthems). Rash appears AFTER fever resolves, hence 'roseola' presentation.
Varicella lesions are in DIFFERENT STAGES simultaneously ('dew drops on rose petals'), with centripetal distribution (trunk >> face/extremities).
Amoxicillin rash with EBV/mononucleosis is NOT a true penicillin allergy and does not contraindicate future penicillin use.
High-dose amoxicillin (80-90 mg/kg/day) for acute otitis media compensates for resistant pneumococcus. First-line for AOM.
In meningitis, dexamethasone (0.15 mg/kg Q6h x 4 days) improves outcomes, especially pneumococcal meningitis. Reduces hearing loss and neurologic complications.
Start antibiotics BEFORE lumbar puncture if bacterial meningitis suspected clinically (petechiae, altered mental status, meningeal signs). Do NOT delay for imaging/LP.
Epiglottitis is an AIRWAY EMERGENCY. Do NOT agitate child, do NOT look in throat at bedside. Visualize only in OR with airway equipment ready. Lateral neck X-ray shows 'thumb sign.'
Pertussis has limited role for antibiotics if already in paroxysmal phase. Most benefit is post-exposure prophylaxis with azithromycin.
Pregnancy during ANY trimester—give Tdap (27-36 weeks preferred) to boost infant immunity and prevent neonatal pertussis.
Purulent cellulitis with drainage now presume MRSA until proven otherwise. Incise and drain; culture; start Vancomycin or Clindamycin empirically.
Scarlet fever rash spares the circumoral area (pastia lines are darkening in skin folds, not absence of rash there). Strawberry tongue is pathognomonic.
Kawasaki disease requires IVIG + high-dose aspirin URGENTLY to prevent coronary artery aneurysms. Diagnosis is clinical: fever >5 days + rash + conjunctival injection + oral changes.
Erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash) in Lyme disease is pathognomonic. Treat immediately with doxycycline (if >8y) or amoxicillin (if <8y) for early disease.
Post-exposure rabies prophylaxis and meningococcal chemoprophylaxis require quick action. Rifampin or cephalosporin prophylaxis for meningococcal contacts.
Varicella vaccine (live) can be given within 3-5 days of varicella exposure for post-exposure prophylaxis. VariZIG (immunoglobulin) for immunocompromised.
TMP-SMX avoided in neonates <2 months due to kernicterus risk (bilirubin displacement). Also contraindicated in G6PD deficiency (hemolysis).

associations.clue: Staccato cough + bilateral diffuse infiltrates in 2-month-old
Barky seal-like cough + inspiratory stridor + hoarseness in 2-year-old
Wheezing + crackles + hyperinflation in 6-month-old
Koplik spots + cough + coryza + conjunctivitis
Slapped-cheek + lacy reticular rash
Fever then rash after fever breaks
Dew drops on rose petals + centripetal distribution
Sandpaper rash + strawberry tongue + pastia lines
Honey crusts on lower extremities
Non-blanching petechial rash + meningeal signs
Fever >5 days + polymorphous rash + conjunctival injection + strawberry tongue
Bull's-eye erythema migrans + tick exposure in endemic area
Petechial rash on wrists/ankles + eschar + tick exposure
Drooling + stridor + tripod positioning + toxic appearance
Acutely limp with hip/knee pain + fever
Acute bone pain (femur/tibia) + fever + edema
Regional lymphadenopathy 2-3 weeks after cat scratch
Vesicular lesions in hand/foot/mouth region + oral ulcers
Pink-red rash on face/trunk + arthralgia (especially adolescent girls)
Osteomyelitis in sickle cell child
Septic arthritis in 2-year-old
associations.answer: Kingella kingae (now most common in this age)

associations.clue: Early-onset sepsis <72 hours + GBS + vertical transmission
Vesicular skin lesions + seizures + maternal genital herpes history
Purulent eye discharge at 2-5 days of life
Perianal itching at night + visible threadlike worms
Walking pneumonia + minimal CXR findings + X-ray worse than clinical picture
Paroxysmal cough with inspiratory whoop after URI
Purulent drainage from cellulitis
Non-purulent cellulitis
Neonatal conjunctivitis at 1-2 weeks with mild discharge

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Permanent tooth discoloration and enamel hypoplasia
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever—doxycycline is first-line at ANY age because RMSF is life-threatening
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: HIGH-YIELD NBME trap: Always offer doxycycline for RMSF regardless of age

sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Generally avoided in children; reserved for serious Pseudomonas infections or cystic fibrosis when no alternatives
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Serious Pseudomonas infection, cystic fibrosis, inhalational anthrax exposure
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Fluoroquinolones contraindicated in most pediatric infections but acceptable for specific life-threatening gram-negative infections

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Aplastic anemia (dose-independent, rare but fatal) and gray baby syndrome in neonates
sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Avoid in neonates; rarely used in modern pediatrics
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Severe rickettsial infections or infections in penicillin-allergic patients (but doxycycline preferred if possible)
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Gray baby syndrome: ashy color, cardiovascular collapse in neonates receiving chloramphenicol—metabolic immaturity causes drug accumulation

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (severe rash), bilirubin displacement (kernicterus in neonates), hemolysis in G6PD deficiency
sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Avoid in neonates <2 months (kernicterus risk) and G6PD-deficient patients
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: PCP prophylaxis/treatment in HIV (gold standard despite risks)
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Bilirubin displacement kernicterus risk in neonates—same mechanism as ceftriaxone/sulfonamides

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Nephrotoxicity (acute tubular necrosis) and ototoxicity (permanent hearing loss—irreversible)
sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Use with caution; requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM)
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Essential for gram-negative coverage in neonatal sepsis/meningitis and Pseudomonas infections
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Toxicity increased when combined with Vancomycin. Monitor peak/trough levels. Extended-interval dosing may reduce toxicity.

sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: AVOID in neonates (<28 days); use cefotaxime instead
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Can use in neonates >28 days or for brief courses if bilirubin low
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Common NBME trap: Using ceftriaxone instead of cefotaxime in neonate with meningitis. Cefotaxime preferred in neonates.

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Metallic taste (very common in children—affects compliance), nausea/vomiting, peripheral neuropathy with prolonged use
sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Can use at any age but poorly tolerated in children
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Necessary for anaerobic coverage in abdominal/CNS infections
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Metallic taste so common in children that alternative agents (clindamycin) often preferred despite efficacy

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Kernicterus in neonates, hemolysis in G6PD deficiency, Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: PCP prophylaxis in HIV (gold standard despite risks)
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Same kernicterus mechanism as ceftriaxone in neonates

sideEffectsContraindications.sideEffect: Permanent tooth discoloration/enamel hypoplasia (especially <8 years), photosensitivity, esophageal ulceration if not taken with water
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Doxycycline FIRST-LINE for RMSF at ANY age (life-threatening disease)
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: The RMSF exception is HIGH-YIELD for shelf exams

sideEffectsContraindications.ageRestriction: Rash appears in ~60% of EBV patients given amoxicillin
sideEffectsContraindications.exception: Rash is NOT an IgE-mediated allergy; safe to use penicillins in future
sideEffectsContraindications.shelfTrap: Parents and patients often label as 'penicillin allergy' but it is NOT a true allergy. Document clearly: 'amoxicillin rash with EBV—not true allergy'

commonBugs.notes: Most common cause of neonatal sepsis. Vertical transmission from maternal GBS colonization (35-40% of women colonized). Risk factors: maternal fever, prolonged rupture of membranes, prematurity. Treatment: Ampicillin + Gentamicin or Cefotaxime.

Second most common cause of neonatal meningitis. K1 capsular antigen crosses blood-brain barrier. Treatment: Ampicillin + Gentamicin or Cefotaxime. Do NOT use ceftriaxone in neonates (kernicterus risk).

presentations: Sepsis (can present as 'granulomatosis infantisepticum' with widespread lesions)
commonBugs.notes: Critical neonatal pathogen especially if mother had fever/diarrhea during pregnancy. CEPHALOSPORINS DO NOT COVER—must use Ampicillin. Treat with Ampicillin + Gentamicin.

Vertical transmission during delivery, especially if maternal primary infection or ruptured vesicles at delivery. Mortality >50% if untreated. Vesicular lesions at 5-14 days of life. CSF with lymphocytes and RBCs (hemorrhagic). Treatment: IV Acyclovir empirically if HSV suspected.
Risk factors: prematurity, prolonged antibiotics, central line, immunodeficiency. Fluconazole or Amphotericin B IV for invasive. Oral fluconazole for thrush.

Late-onset GBS differs from early-onset: different capsular types, no maternal fever association. Empiric coverage: Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin (Listeria coverage less critical but may still be given).
Increasing antibiotic resistance. Some serotypes resistant to penicillin. Empiric coverage for meningitis: high-dose cephalosporin + Vancomycin. Vaccine-preventable (PCV13).
Now rare in vaccinated populations. Still see unvaccinated/under-vaccinated children. Cephalosporin coverage essential. Hib vaccine highly successful.
Peak age 2-12 months. Wheezing, crackles, hyperinflation. Viral—supportive care. Palivizumab (monoclonal antibody) prophylaxis for high-risk preemies.
Vaccine-preventable (rotavirus vaccine). Less severe now with vaccination. Presents with watery diarrhea, vomiting, fever.
Still leading cause of bacterial meningitis in this age despite vaccination. High-dose amoxicillin for AOM (80-90 mg/kg/day). Vaccine: PCV13.
Can cause rapid progression to septic shock. Characteristic non-blanching petechial rash. Cephalosporin coverage. Vaccine: MenACWY and MenB (separate).
Type b rare with Hib vaccine. Non-typeable increasingly common cause of AOM. Often beta-lactamase positive (resistant to ampicillin). Treat with high-dose amoxicillin-clavulanate or cephalosporin.
Fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus. Replaced S. aureus as most common cause of septic arthritis in toddlers. Requires longer treatment. Cephalosporin or susceptible Ampicillin.

presentations: Septic arthritis (less common than Kingella in toddlers)
commonBugs.notes: MRSA increasingly common. Purulent infections likely MRSA—do I&D and start Vancomycin or Clindamycin (if susceptible). MSSA: nafcillin or cephalosporin preferred.

presentations: Otitis media (less common than in younger kids)
commonBugs.notes: Still leading cause of bacterial pneumonia. Vaccine: PCV13 (all children should have completed series), PPSV23 (for chronic disease/immunocompromise).
Increasingly common in school-age and adolescents. Minimal findings on exam but extensive infiltrates on CXR. Treated with azithromycin or doxycycline (if >8 years).
Gold standard diagnosis: throat culture. Treat with 10-day Amoxicillin/Penicillin course to prevent acute rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal GN.
Tick exposure in endemic areas (Northeast, Midwest US). Bull's-eye rash (erythema migrans) pathognomonic. Treat with doxycycline (if >8y) or amoxicillin (if <8y) for early disease.
MRSA presume if purulent drainage present. Culture and susceptibilities guide therapy. I&D essential for abscesses.
Still cause of serious infections. Vaccination status important (should have completed PCV13 + PPSV23 if appropriate).

presentations: Community-acquired pneumonia (very common in this age)
commonBugs.notes: 'Walking pneumonia.' Minimal exam findings, extensive CXR infiltrates (X-ray looks worse than patient). Treat with azithromycin or doxycycline.
STI screening essential in sexually active adolescents. Dual therapy: Ceftriaxone + Azithromycin (or Doxycycline). Fluoroquinolones no longer recommended due to resistance.
Often co-infected with gonorrhea. Azithromycin or doxycycline. Screen all sexually active adolescents.

presentations: Secondary syphilis (rash on trunk/palms/soles, systemic symptoms)
commonBugs.notes: Resurgence in adolescents. Screen all sexually active. Treat with benzathine Penicillin G IM single dose or doxycycline.
